en_first_half: From the corner of the divan of Persian saddle-bags on which he was lying, smoking, as was his custom, innumerable cigarettes, Lord Henry Wotton could just catch the gleam of the honey-sweet and honey-coloured blossoms of a laburnum, whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden of a beauty so flamelike as theirs; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in flight flitted across the long tussore-silk curtains that were stretched in front of the huge window, producing a kind
en_second_half: of momentary Japanese effect, and making him think of those pallid, jade-faced painters of Tokyo who, through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile, seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion. The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass, or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine, seemed to make the stillness more oppressive. The dim roar of London was like the bourdon note of a distant organ.

en_results_raw: The effect of a fleeting, ethereal dance, as if the very essence of the garden had been distilled onto the walls of the room. The scent of jasmine and orange blossoms wafted in on the gentle breeze, mingling with the acrid smell of Lord Henry's cigarette smoke, creating a heady, intoxicating aroma that seemed to wrap itself around his senses like a warm, golden mist. As he lay there, lost in the languid haze of the afternoon, he felt his thoughts begin to wander, drifting lazily from one subject to another, like a leaf on a stream, until they finally came to rest on the face of his friend, Dorian Gray, whose portrait hung on the wall opposite, watching him with an enigmatic, almost otherworldly smile. The painting seemed to be gazing at him with an intensity that was almost palpable, as if it held some secret, some hidden truth that only he could see, and Lord Henry felt a shiver run down his spine as he wondered what it might be.

es_first_half: Lord Henry Wotton, que había consumido ya, según su costumbre, innumerables cigarrillos, vislumbraba, desde el extremo del sofá donde estaba tumbado —tapizado al estilo de las alfombras persas—, el resplandor de las floraciones de un codeso, de dulzura y color de miel, cuyas ramas estremecidas apenas parecían capaces de soportar el peso de una belleza tan deslumbrante como la suya; y, de cuando en cuando, las sombras fantásticas de pájaros en vuelo se deslizaban sobre las largas cortinas de seda india colgadas delante de las inmensas ventanas, produciendo algo así
es_second_half: como un efecto japonés, lo que le hacía pensar en los pintores de Tokyo, de rostros tan pálidos como el jade, que, por medio de un arte necesariamente inmóvil, tratan de transmitir la sensación de velocidad y de movimiento. El zumbido obstinado de las abejas, abriéndose camino entre el alto césped sin segar, o dando vueltas con monótona insistencia en torno a los polvorientos cuernos dorados de las desordenadas madreselvas, parecían hacer más opresiva la quietud, mientras los ruidos confusos de Londres eran como las notas graves de un órgano lejano.

"¿Qué hay, Dorian?", preguntó Lord Henry, sin poder disimular la curiosidad en su voz, mientras se sentaba más erguido en el sofá, preparado para escuchar lo que su amigo iba a decirle.

en_first_half: In the centre of the room, clamped to an upright easel, stood the full-length portrait of a young man of extraordinary personal beauty, and in front of it, some little
en_second_half: distance away, was sitting the artist himself, Basil Hallward, whose sudden disappearance some years ago caused, at the time, such public excitement and gave rise to so many strange conjectures.
en_results: The delicate, lace-trimmed chair, its velvet cushions a deep, rich purple, seemed to be waiting for someone, its occupant's absence only adding to the sense of anticipation that hung in the air.
en_results_raw: The delicate, lace-trimmed chair, its velvet cushions a deep, rich purple, seemed to be waiting for someone, its occupant's absence only adding to the sense of anticipation that hung in the air. The young man in the portrait, with his piercing blue eyes and chiseled features, seemed to be gazing directly into the very soul of the room, his enigmatic smile hinting at secrets and stories yet untold. The soft, golden light that streamed through the tall windows cast a warm glow on the entire scene, illuminating the intricate patterns on the Persian rug and the delicate carvings on the antique furniture, creating an atmosphere of elegance and refinement that was almost palpable. As the eye wandered around the room, it was drawn to the numerous objects that adorned the walls and shelves, each one a testament to the owner's refined taste and love of the arts. A beautifully crafted music box sat atop a nearby console table, its delicate ballerina twirling to the tune of a soft, melancholic melody, while a nearby vase held a stunning bouquet of fresh flowers, their sweet fragrance wafting through the air and adding to the sense of serenity that pervaded the space. The overall effect was one of understated luxury, a subtle yet unmistakable sense of wealth and sophistication that seemed to emanate from every corner of the room.

en_results_raw: The warm sunlight and the sweet scent of blooming flowers enveloped them as they strolled along the winding path, their footsteps quiet on the soft grass. Lord Henry, with his quick wit and charming smile, regaled his companions with tales of his adventures in the city, leaving them in stitches with his clever impressions and witty remarks. Meanwhile, the sound of a nearby fountain provided a soothing background melody, its gentle gurgling a perfect accompaniment to their lively conversation. As they walked, the trees cast dappled shadows on the ground, creating a sense of tranquility that belied the mischievous glint in Lord Henry's eye. His companions, though initially taken aback by his provocative statement, found themselves drawn into his world of sophistication and elegance, where the boundaries between reality and artifice blurred, and the art of being natural was reduced to a mere facade.

es_results_raw: un banco de piedra, donde el sol de la tarde los envolvía con su cálido abrazo. La conversación fluyó con facilidad, hablando de todo y de nada, de libros, de música, de arte, de la vida y de la muerte, sin que nadie se sintiera obligado a tomar una postura o a defender una opinión. La risa de lord Henry era contagiosa, y pronto se unió a ella, aunque con un toque de ironía, como si se burlara de sí mismo y de la situación. El aire estaba lleno de la fragancia de las flores y el canto de los pájaros, creando un ambiente de paz y armonía que parecía alejar cualquier preocupación o problema. La noche comenzaba a caer, y el cielo se teñía de colores pastel, un espectáculo que siempre había sido su favorito. Lord Henry se levantó del banco y se acercó a la fuente, donde se reflejaba el cielo en el agua, creando un efecto de infinito que parecía transportarlo a otro mundo. "¿Te has dado cuenta de que la vida es como un cuadro de arte?", preguntó, volviéndose hacia su amigo. "Un cuadro que cambia con cada pincelada, con cada paso del tiempo, y que siempre nos sorprende con su belleza y su complejidad". Su amigo asintió en silencio, sin necesidad de palabras, ya que sabía que lord Henry estaba hablando de algo más profundo, algo que iba más allá de la superficie de la vida cotidiana. La noche se había hecho más oscura, pero el calor del sol de la tarde seguía presente, como un recuerdo que no quería desaparecer. La conversación se prolongó durante horas, sin que nadie se diera cuenta del paso del tiempo, hasta que la luna comenzó a brillar en el cielo, iluminando el jardín con su luz suave y silenciosa.

They have all understood that the key to true happiness lies not in the suppression of the senses, but in their liberation. La escritura es una forma de expresión que nos permite comunicar nuestros pensamientos y sentimientos de manera auténtica, y aunque no todos podemos ser famosos, podemos encontrar nuestra propia voz y conectar con los demás a través de nuestras palabras. Recuerdo que cuando era joven, soñaba con escribir novelas épicas y ganar premios literarios, pero con el tiempo me di cuenta de que la verdadera felicidad no se encuentra en la fama o el reconocimiento, sino en la satisfacción de crear algo que sea auténtico y significativo. Ahora, como editor, me encanta descubrir nuevos talentos y ayudar a los escritores a compartir sus historias con el mundo. ¿Y usted, qué le motiva a escribir? ¿Qué le gusta de la literatura? ¿Qué le hace sentir que su historia es importante? en_first_half: “It is an interesting question,” said Lord Henry, who found an exquisite pleasure in playing on the lad’s unconscious egotism, “an extremely interesting question. I fancy that the true explanation is this: It often happens that the real tragedies of life occur in such an inartistic manner that they hurt us by their crude violence, their absolute incoherence, their absurd want of meaning, their entire lack of style. They affect us just as vulgarity affects us. They give us an impression of sheer brute force, and we revolt against that. Sometimes, however, a tragedy that possesses artistic elements of beauty crosses our lives. If these elements of beauty are real, the whole thing simply appeals to our sense of dramatic effect. Suddenly we find that we are no longer the actors, but the spectators of the play. Or rather we are both. We watch ourselves,
en_second_half: and the mere wonder of the spectacle enthralls us. In the present case, what is it that has really happened? Some one has killed herself for love of you. I wish that I had ever had such an experience. It would have made me in love with love for the rest of my life. The people who have adored me—there have not been very many, but there have been some—have always insisted on living on, long after I had ceased to care for them, or they to care for me. They have become stout and tedious, and when I meet them, they go in at once for reminiscences. That awful memory of woman! What a fearful thing it is! And what an utter intellectual stagnation it reveals! One should absorb the colour of life, but one should never remember its details. Details are always vulgar.”

es_first_half: —Es un caso interesante —dijo lord Henry, que encontraba un placer sutil enjugar con el egoísmo inconsciente de su joven amigo—; un caso sumamente interesante. Creo que la verdadera explicación es ésta: sucede con frecuencia que las tragedias reales de la vida ocurren de una manera tan poco artística que nos hieren por lo crudo de su violencia, por su absoluta incoherencia, su absurda ausencia de significado, su completa falta de estilo. Nos afectan como lo hace la vulgaridad. Sólo nos producen una impresión de fuerza bruta, y nos rebelamos contra eso. A veces, sin embargo, cruza nuestras vidas una tragedia que posee elementos de belleza artística. Si esos elementos de belleza son reales, todo el conjunto apela a nuestro sentido del efecto dramático. De repente descubrimos que ya no somos los actores, sino los espectadores de la obra. O que
es_second_half: somos más bien las dos cosas. Nos observamos, y el mero asombro del espectáculo nos seduce. En el caso presente, ¿qué es lo que ha sucedido en realidad? Alguien se ha matado por amor tuyo. Me gustaría haber tenido alguna vez una experiencia semejante. Me hubiera hecho enamorarme del amor para el resto de mi vida. Las personas que me han adorado (no han sido muchas, pero sí algunas), siempre han insistido en seguir viviendo después de que yo dejase de quererlas y ellas dejaran de quererme a mí. Se han vuelto corpulentas y tediosas, y cuando me encuentro con ellas se lanzan inmediatamente a los recuerdos. ¡Ah, esa terrible memoria de las mujeres! ¡Qué cosa más espantosa! ¡Y qué total estancamiento intelectual revela! Se deben absorberlos colores de la vida, pero nunca recordar los detalles. Los detalles siempre son vulgares.

en_results_raw: The dreadful thing, the thing that had brought him such unhappiness and guilt. He carefully lifted the coverlet and draped it over the object, the gold embroidery glinting in the dim light of the room. The soft, luxurious fabric seemed to swallow the thing whole, and for a moment, Dorian felt a sense of relief wash over him. But it was short-lived, as he knew that the coverlet would only serve as a temporary solution, a Band-Aid on a much deeper wound. He thought back to the events that had led him to this point, the reckless abandon with which he had pursued his desires, the hurt he had caused to those around him. The coverlet seemed to mock him, its beauty and opulence a cruel reminder of the emptiness within. He knew that he had to get rid of the thing, to rid himself of its influence, but a part of him was reluctant to let go, to surrender to the consequences of his actions. The room seemed to grow darker, the shadows deepening as he stood there, frozen in indecision. He knew that he had to make a choice, to take a step towards redemption, but the fear of the unknown held him back. The coverlet seemed to be watching him, its silence a reminder that he was not alone in this struggle. And then, as if sensing his turmoil, the clock on the mantle struck the hour, its sonorous tones echoing through the room, a stark reminder that time was running out.

Se acercó al cubrecama y lo tomó en sus manos, sintiendo el suave tacto del satén y el brillo de los bordados en oro. Dorian se preguntó si alguna vez podría encontrar la paz, o si la memoria de su amado siempre estaría con él, como un dolor constante que no se iba a aliviar. Pero Dorian sabía que no era tan fácil, que la muerte de su amado había dejado un vacío en su corazón que no se iba a llenar nunca. Se quedó allí, con el cubrecama en sus manos, sintiendo el peso de su tristeza y la nostalgia que lo invadía. Finalmente, con un suspiro, decidió seguir adelante, sabiendo que no podía quedarse allí para siempre, pero sin saber si alguna vez podría encontrar la paz. en_results_raw: The beauty and the joy of life, for it was to be a philosophy that would not only cater to the senses but also to the soul. It was to be a celebration of individuality, a rejection of the stifling conventions that had held people back for so long. This new Hedonism would not be about excess or decadence, but about living life to the fullest, about experiencing all that the world had to offer, and about finding true fulfillment in the process. It would be a philosophy that would encourage people to explore their desires, to indulge in their passions, and to live life on their own terms. And yet, it would also be a philosophy that would not abandon reason or intellect, but would instead use them to guide and inform one's experiences, to ensure that they were not merely fleeting pleasures, but meaningful and enriching ones. It would be a delicate balance, to be sure, but one that would allow people to live life with purpose and intention, and to find happiness and contentment in the midst of it all.

es_results_raw: <output>de la vida, que no fuera incompatible con la búsqueda de la felicidad y la plenitud. La gente comenzaba a cuestionar las normas y valores tradicionales, a buscar nuevas formas de expresión y placer, y lord Henry, con su visión de un hedonismo intelectualizado, se encontraba en el epicentro de este movimiento. Sin embargo, su visión no era tan sencilla como parecía, y pronto se daría cuenta de que la búsqueda de la felicidad y la plenitud no era tan fácil de alcanzar como había imaginado. La sociedad estaba llena de contradicciones y complejidades, y la búsqueda de la perfección era un camino lleno de obstáculos y desafíos. A medida que avanzaba en su búsqueda, lord Henry se encontraría con que la realidad era más compleja y matizada de lo que había imaginado, y que la verdadera felicidad y plenitud requerían algo más que la simple búsqueda del placer. La verdadera cuestión era si estaba dispuesto a enfrentar los desafíos y contradicciones que se presentaban en su camino, o si se rendiría a la tentación de la comodidad y la facilidad. La respuesta a esta pregunta sería determinante para su futuro, y para el de la sociedad en la que vivía. La búsqueda de la felicidad y la plenitud se convertiría en un viaje de descubrimiento y crecimiento, lleno de altibajos y sorpresas, pero también de oportunidades para aprender y crecer. Y lord Henry, con su visión de un hedonismo intelectualizado, se encontraría en el centro de este viaje, luchando por encontrar la respuesta a la pregunta que lo había llevado a comenzar su búsqueda en primer lugar: ¿qué es la felicidad, y cómo se puede alcanzar? La literatura era para él un refugio, un lugar donde podía escapar de la dura realidad y sumergirse en un mundo de ficción, donde los personajes y las historias se convierten en una extensión de su propia alma. A menudo se preguntaba si no sería él mismo el protagonista de una de esas historias, si no sería su vida la que estaba siendo escrita por algún autor invisible, con un propósito y un destino que él no podía controlar. La idea le resultaba a la vez aterradora y fascinante, y le hacía sentir que estaba viviendo en un estado de suspensión, entre la realidad y la ficción, sin saber qué era lo que era real y qué era lo que era solo una ilusión. En ese estado de confusión, Dorian se sentía libre para explorar sus propios deseos y pasiones, sin temor a las consecuencias, ya que creía que todo era solo una historia, una historia que él mismo estaba escribiendo, y que podía cambiar a su antojo. Pero, a medida que pasaba el tiempo, comenzó a darse cuenta de que la línea entre la realidad y la ficción se estaba volviendo cada vez más difusa, y que no estaba seguro de qué era lo que estaba sucediendo en realidad. La incertidumbre le resultaba agotadora, y comenzó a sentir que estaba perdiendo el control de su propia vida, como si estuviera siendo arrastrado por una corriente que él no podía detener. La sensación de desorientación y confusión se apoderó de él, y se sintió como si estuviera sumergido en un mar de dudas y miedos, sin saber cómo encontrar la orilla. La búsqueda de la juventud y la belleza se había convertido en una obsesión, y Dorian se sentía atrapado en un ciclo de lujuria y decadencia, sin saber cómo escapar. La sombra de su propio destino se cernía sobre él, y no podía evitar preguntarse si no sería demasiado tarde para cambiar el curso de su vida, o si ya estaba condenado a seguir el camino que había elegido. La incertidumbre y la duda se habían convertido en su compañeros constantes, y Dorian se sentía solo y abandonado, sin saber qué camino tomar. en_first_half: “Years ago, when I was a boy,” said Dorian Gray, crushing the flower in his hand, “you met me, flattered me, and taught me to be vain of my good looks. One day you introduced me to a friend of yours, who explained to me
en_second_half: the wonder of youth, and you finished a portrait of me that revealed to me the wonder of beauty. In a mad moment that, even now, I don’t know whether I regret or not, I made a wish, perhaps you would call it a prayer....”
en_results: The theory of aestheticism, and how the pursuit of beauty and youth was the ultimate goal of human existence. I was enthralled by his words, and from that moment on, I became obsessed with the idea of eternal youth and beauty.
en_results_raw: The theory of aestheticism, and how the pursuit of beauty and youth was the ultimate goal of human existence. I was enthralled by his words, and from that moment on, I became obsessed with the idea of eternal youth and beauty. I spent hours in front of the mirror, admiring my reflection, and I began to notice the subtle changes in my appearance, the way my eyes sparkled, the way my skin glowed. I became convinced that I was invincible, that I could cheat death and remain forever young and beautiful. And so, I made a pact with myself to do whatever it took to preserve my youth, to keep myself looking perfect, no matter the cost. I started to lead a double life, hiding my true nature from the world, while I indulged in all the vices and excesses that I desired. I became a master of deception, a chameleon, able to change my appearance and my personality to suit the situation. But deep down, I knew that I was playing with fire, that my obsession with beauty and youth was a curse, a never-ending cycle of vanity and self-destruction. And yet, I couldn't stop, I was addicted to the thrill of it all, the rush of adrenaline that came with each new conquest, each new sin. I was a slave to my own desires, a prisoner of my own vanity, and I knew that I would never be free.

Mi amigo, Lord Henry, me enseñó a explorar mis deseos y a satisfacer mis necesidades, y juntos creamos un mundo de lujuria y decadencia. Pero con el tiempo, comencé a darme cuenta de que mi belleza era un doble filo, que me otorgaba la capacidad de seducir y manipular a los demás, pero también me condenaba a vivir en la sombra de mi propia imagen. Mi amigo, con su pasión y su amor, se convirtió en mi refugio, mi confidente y mi verdadero amor, pero también se convirtió en mi prisión, ya que no podía soportar la idea de perderlo. Y así, me encontré atrapado en un ciclo de amor y dolor, de belleza y decadencia, que me llevó a hacer un trato con el diablo, un trato que me otorgó la inmortalidad, pero a cambio de mi alma.

en_results_raw: soundly, his chest rising and falling with a slow, measured rhythm, his face pale and drawn, his lips slightly parted. The servant set the tray down on the bedside table and stood for a moment, watching him, before quietly withdrawing. The sunlight streaming through the open shutters cast a warm glow over the room, illuminating the dust motes dancing in the air and highlighting the intricate patterns on the wallpaper. Dorian stirred, his eyes fluttering open, and he sat up with a start, rubbing his eyes as if trying to shake off the remnants of a dream. He swung his legs over the side of the bed and planted his feet firmly on the ground, feeling the cool, smooth wood beneath his toes. The chocolate on the tray seemed to be calling to him, and he reached out a hand to take the cup, the rich aroma wafting up to greet him as he lifted the lid and took a sip. The bitter taste was a welcome respite from the lingering fogginess in his mind, and he felt a sense of clarity begin to wash over him as he sat there, savoring the flavor and the quiet morning moment to himself.

en_results_raw: the clock struck the hour, and the doorbell rang. Dorian's heart skipped a beat as he rose from his chair, his eyes fixed on the door. He smoothed his hair, adjusted his tie, and took a deep breath, trying to compose himself. The sound of footsteps echoed from the hallway, growing louder with each passing moment, and Dorian's anxiety reached a fever pitch. He had been waiting for what felt like an eternity for this moment, and now that it was finally here, he couldn't help but wonder if he was truly ready. The door creaked open, and a tall, imposing figure stood in the entrance, his piercing gaze scanning the room as if searching for something or someone. Dorian's eyes locked onto the stranger, and he felt a shiver run down his spine as their eyes met in a silent understanding. The air was thick with tension as the two men stood there, frozen in a moment of mutual anticipation, the only sound the soft ticking of the clock on the mantle.

He took a step back, his heart racing with a mix of fear and curiosity, wondering what secrets the portrait held, and what had driven him to tear the curtain that fateful night. As he stood there, frozen in uncertainty, he heard a faint whisper in his ear, a soft, raspy voice that seemed to be calling his name, "Dorian..." The voice sent a chill down his spine, and he spun around, but there was no one there. The whisper seemed to come from all around him, echoing off the walls, and he felt a presence closing in on him, making his skin crawl. es_results_raw: tranquilo, y se dirigió directamente a la mesa donde estaba sentado el bibliotecario, un hombre de edad avanzada con gafas redondas y un bigote blanco. Campbell se detuvo frente a él y comenzó a hablar en voz baja, como si temiera ser escuchado por alguien más. "Señor bibliotecario, necesito hablar con usted sobre algo muy importante", dijo, su voz temblorosa. El bibliotecario lo miró con curiosidad y asintió con la cabeza, invitándolo a sentarse. Campbell se sentó y comenzó a explicar su historia, contando sobre el extraño libro que había encontrado en la estantería y sobre los sueños que lo habían estado persiguiendo desde entonces. El bibliotecario lo escuchó atentamente, su rostro impasible, pero Campbell notó que sus ojos se habían vuelto más brillantes a medida que hablaba, como si estuviera viendo algo que Campbell no podía ver. Cuando Campbell terminó de hablar, el bibliotecario se quedó en silencio durante un momento, como si estuviera pensando en algo. Luego, se levantó y se dirigió a una estantería en la pared más lejana de la biblioteca, donde sacó un libro antiguo y lo abrió en una página marcada con un pedazo de papel. "¿Sabe qué es esto?", preguntó, mostrándole el libro a Campbell. Campbell se acercó para mirar y vio que la página estaba llena de símbolos y dibujos extraños. "¿Qué significa?", preguntó, sintiendo un escalofrío en la espalda. El bibliotecario sonrió y se sentó de nuevo en su silla, como si estuviera a punto de revelar un secreto. "Es un libro de hechizos", dijo, su voz baja y misteriosa. "Un libro que contiene los secretos de la magia oscura". Campbell se sintió como si hubiera sido golpeado por un rayo. ¿Qué estaba pasando? ¿Qué tipo de biblioteca era esta? ¿Y qué tipo de libro era ese? Se sintió atraído por el libro, como si estuviera siendo arrastrado por una fuerza invisible. Quería saber más, quería saber todo. Pero el bibliotecario se levantó de nuevo y se dirigió a la puerta, como si estuviera a punto de irse. "No puede quedarse aquí", dijo, su voz firme. "No puede quedarse aquí". Campbell se sintió confundido, pero el bibliotecario ya se había ido, dejándolo solo en la biblioteca. Se quedó sentado allí, mirando el libro de hechizos, sintiendo que su vida estaba a punto de cambiar para siempre.

en_first_half: It is said that passion makes one think in a circle. Certainly with hideous iteration the bitten lips of Dorian Gray shaped and reshaped those subtle words that dealt with soul and sense, till he had found in them the full expression, as it were, of his mood, and justified, by intellectual approval, passions that without such justification would still have dominated his temper. From cell to cell of his brain crept the one thought; and the wild desire to live, most terrible of all man’s appetites, quickened
en_second_half: into force each trembling nerve and fibre. Ugliness that had once been hateful to him because it made things real, became dear to him now for that very reason. Ugliness was the one reality. The coarse brawl, the loathsome den, the crude violence of disordered life, the very vileness of thief and outcast, were more vivid, in their intense actuality of impression, than all the gracious shapes of art, the dreamy shadows of song. They were what he needed for forgetfulness. In three days he would be free.

Era como si, en el corazón de la tempestad, hubiera encontrado un refugio seguro, un lugar donde podía esconderse de la realidad y permitirse el lujo de ser él mismo, sin importar las consecuencias de sus actos. Y así, con cada nuevo capítulo de su vida, Dorian Gray se sumergía en la oscuridad de su alma, sin importar el precio que tuviera que pagar por su pasión, y sin importar el daño que causara a los demás. Su corazón se había convertido en un laberinto de pasiones y deseos, donde la razón y la conciencia habían sido expulsadas, y solo la pasión y el instinto reinaban supremos. Y en ese laberinto, Dorian Gray se había perdido, sin saber cómo encontrar el camino de regreso a la luz, ni siquiera siquiera quería hacerlo.

en_results_raw: The air was thick with the scent of smoke and decay, and the flickering candles cast eerie shadows on the walls. Dorian's heart quickened as he reached the top of the stairs, his eyes adjusting slowly to the dim light. The room was small, with a single, ornate mirror hanging on the wall, its surface cloudy with age. A figure sat huddled in the corner, surrounded by the remnants of a long-forgotten feast. The air was heavy with the weight of secrets, and Dorian felt a shiver run down his spine as he stepped further into the room. He could feel the weight of the past bearing down on him, and he knew that he was not alone. The figure slowly looked up, its eyes locking onto Dorian's, and for a moment, they simply stared at each other, the only sound the soft crackling of the candles.

The gardener, a stout man with a bushy mustache, was indeed standing by the entrance, his eyes fixed intently on the young woman, his face a picture of concern. Lord Henry's smile faltered for a moment as he watched the exchange, his mind racing with possibilities. He had always known that the gardener was a bit of a gossip, but he had never thought he would be the one to deliver news that would change everything. The young woman's eyes were fixed on the gardener, her face pale and drawn, and Lord Henry could sense the tension building between them. He cleared his throat to break the silence, but before he could speak, the gardener stepped forward, his voice low and gravelly, and said, "Miss, I'm afraid I have some news that may upset you."

They are always rushing into the unknown, never content to stay in the safety of their own little world, but always seeking to explore the uncharted territories of life, to test their limits, and to push the boundaries of what is considered acceptable. And it is this very quality that makes them so alluring, so captivating, and so utterly irresistible to us men. Whether it is a reckless abandon of convention, a daring disregard for the rules, or a bold willingness to take risks, women have a way of making us feel alive, of making us feel like we are a part of something greater than ourselves, something that transcends the mundane and the ordinary. Y es precisamente esa cualidad lo que atrae a lord Henry, que siempre ha sido un apasionado de las mujeres fuertes y aventureras, y que ha pasado su vida rodeado de ellas, admirándolas y admirándose a sí mismo por su capacidad para atraerlas.

en_first_half: “My dear boy,” said Lord Henry, smiling, “anybody can be good in the country. There are no temptations there. That is the reason why people who live out of town are so absolutely uncivilized. Civilization is not by any
en_second_half: means an easy thing to attain to. There are only two ways by which man can reach it. One is by being cultured, the other by being corrupt. Country people have no opportunity of being either, so they stagnate.”
en_results: completion> means that civilization is not by any means to be associated with a particular place or a particular set of people, but rather it is a product of the mind, and it is the result of the constant struggle
en_results_raw: completion> means that civilization is not by any means to be associated with a particular place or a particular set of people, but rather it is a product of the mind, and it is the result of the constant struggle between good and evil, between virtue and vice. It is the ability to resist the temptations of the world, to stand firm in the face of adversity, and to remain true to one's principles, that truly defines a civilized person. And it is precisely this ability that is lacking in those who live in the country, where the temptations are few and the opportunities for self-improvement are limited. Lord Henry's words were a veiled criticism of the superficiality of country life, where people are often content with a shallow existence, unchallenged by the complexities and nuances of city life. He was suggesting that true civilization requires a certain level of sophistication, a certain level of exposure to the world, and a certain level of moral fibre, all of which are in short supply in the country. And yet, as he spoke, he couldn't help but feel a twinge of envy for those who lived in the country, who were free from the corruptions and the stresses of city life, and who were able to live in harmony with nature. He knew that he himself was a product of the city, and that his own values and morals had been shaped by the very temptations and corruptions that he was now criticizing. And so, he smiled to himself, knowing that he was caught in a paradox, and that his words were laced with hypocrisy. But he pushed on, determined to make his point, and to convince his young friend of the importance of living in the city, where the action was, and where the real battle for civilization was being fought.

As I passed by, I heard the man yelling out that question to his audience. It struck me as being rather dramatic. London
en_second_half: is very rich in curious effects of that kind. A wet Sunday, an uncouth Christian in a mackintosh, a ring of sickly white faces under a broken roof of dripping umbrellas, and a wonderful phrase flung into the air by shrill hysterical lips—it was really very good in its way, quite a suggestion. I thought of telling the prophet that art had a soul, but that man had not. I am afraid, however, he would not have understood me.”
